author: Potter
text: This is a Tale about a tail--a tail that belonged to a little red squirrel, and his name was Nutkin.

author: Potter
text: He had a brother called Twinkleberry, and a great many cousins: they lived in a wood at the edge of a lake.

author: Potter
text: In the middle of the lake there is an island covered with trees and nut bushes; and amongst those trees stands a hollow oak-tree, which is the house of an owl who is called Old Brown.

author: Potter
text: One autumn when the nuts were ripe, and the leaves on the hazel bushes were golden and green-- Nutkin and Twinkleberry and all the other little squirrels came out of the wood, and down to the edge of the lake.

author: Potter
text: They made little rafts out of twigs, and they paddled away over the water to Owl Island to gather nuts.

author: Potter
text: Each squirrel had a little sack and a large oar, and spread out his tail for a sail.

author: Potter
text: They also took with them an offering of three fat mice as a present for Old Brown, and put them down upon his door-step.

author: Potter
text: Then Twinkleberry and the other little squirrels each made a low bow, and said politely--

author: Potter
text: "Old Mr. Brown, will you favour us with permission to gather nuts upon your island?"

author: Potter
text: But Nutkin was excessively impertinent in his manners.

author: Potter
text: He bobbed up and down like a little red CHERRY, singing--

author: Potter
text: "Riddle me, riddle me, rot-tot-tote!

author: Potter
text: A little wee man, in a red red coat!

author: Potter
text: A staff in his hand, and a stone in his throat; If you'll tell me this riddle, I'll give you a groat."

author: Potter
text: Now this riddle is as old as the hills; Mr. Brown paid no attention whatever to Nutkin.

author: Potter
text: He shut his eyes obstinately and went to sleep.

author: Potter
text: The squirrels filled their little sacks with nuts, and sailed away home in the evening.

author: Potter
text: But next morning they all came back again to Owl Island; and Twinkleberry and the others brought a fine fat mole, and laid it on the stone in front of Old Brown's doorway, and said--

author: Potter
text: "Mr. Brown, will you favour us with your gracious permission to gather some more nuts?"

author: Potter
text: But Nutkin, who had no respect, began to dance up and down, tickling old Mr. Brown with a NETTLE and singing--

author: Potter
text: "Old Mr. B!

author: Potter
text: Riddle-me-ree!

author: Potter
text: Hitty Pitty within the wall, Hitty Pitty without the wall; If you touch Hitty Pitty, Hitty Pitty will bite you!"

author: Potter
text: Mr. Brown woke up suddenly and carried the mole into his house.

author: Potter
text: He shut the door in Nutkin's face.

author: Potter
text: Presently a little thread of blue SMOKE from a wood fire came up from the top of the tree, and Nutkin peeped through the key-hole and sang--

author: Potter
text: "A house full, a hole full!

author: Potter
text: And you cannot gather a bowl-full!"

author: Potter
text: The squirrels searched for nuts all over the island and filled their little sacks.

author: Potter
text: But Nutkin gathered oak-apples-- yellow and scarlet--and sat upon a beech-stump playing marbles, and watching the door of old Mr. Brown.

author: Potter
text: On the third day the squirrels got up very early and went fishing; they caught seven fat minnows as a present for Old Brown.

author: Potter
text: They paddled over the lake and landed under a crooked chestnut tree on Owl Island.

author: Potter
text: Twinkleberry and six other little squirrels each carried a fat minnow; but Nutkin, who had no nice manners, brought no present at all.

author: Potter
text: He ran in front, singing--

author: Potter
text: "The man in the wilderness said to me, `How may strawberries grow in the sea?'

author: Potter
text: I answered him as I thought good-- `As many red herrings as grow in the wood."'

author: Potter
text: But old Mr. Brown took no interest in riddles--not even when the answer was provided for him.

author: Potter
text: On the fourth day the squirrels brought a present of six fat beetles, which were as good as plums in PLUM-PUDDING for Old Brown.

author: Potter
text: Each beetle was wrapped up carefully in a dockleaf, fastened with a pine-needle- pin.

author: Potter
text: But Nutkin sang as rudely as ever--

author: Potter
text: "Old Mr. B! riddle-me-ree!

author: Potter
text: Flour of England, fruit of Spain, Met together in a shower of rain; Put in a bag tied round with a string, If you'll tell me this riddle, I'll give you a ring!"

author: Potter
text: Which was ridiculous of Nutkin, because he had not got any ring to give to Old Brown.

author: Potter
text: The other squirrels hunted up and down the nut bushes; but Nutkin gathered robin's pin-cushions off a briar bush, and stuck them full of pine-needle-pins.

author: Potter
text: On the fifth day the squirrels brought a present of wild honey; it was so sweet and sticky that they licked their fingers as they put it down upon the stone.

author: Potter
text: They had stolen it out of a bumble BEES' nest on the tippity top of the hill.

author: Potter
text: But Nutkin skipped up and down, singing--

author: Potter
text: "Hum-a-bum! buzz! buzz!

author: Potter
text: Hum-a-bum buzz!

author: Potter
text: As I went over Tipple-tine I met a flock of bonny swine; Some yellow-nacked, some yellow backed!

author: Potter
text: They were the very bonniest swine That e'er went over the Tipple-tine."

author: Potter
text: Old Mr. Brown turned up his eyes in disgust at the impertinence of Nutkin.

author: Potter
text: But he ate up the honey!

author: Potter
text: The squirrels filled their little sacks with nuts.

author: Potter
text: But Nutkin sat upon a big flat rock, and played ninepins with a crab apple and green fir-cones.

author: Potter
text: On the sixth day, which was Saturday, the squirrels came again for the last time; they brought a new-laid EGG in a little rush basket as a last parting present for Old Brown.

author: Potter
text: But Nutkin ran in front laughing, and shouting--

author: Potter
text: "Humpty Dumpty lies in the beck, With a white counterpane round his neck, Forty doctors and forty wrights, Cannot put Humpty Dumpty to rights!"

author: Potter
text: Now old Mr. Brown took an interest in eggs; he opened one eye and shut it again.

author: Potter
text: But still he did not speak.

author: Potter
text: Nutkin became more and more impertinent--

author: Potter
text: "Old Mr. B!

author: Potter
text: Old Mr. B!

author: Potter
text: Hickamore, Hackamore, on the King's kitchen door; All the King's horses, and all the King's men, Couldn't drive Hickamore, Hackamore, Off the King's kitchen door!"

author: Potter
text: Nutkin danced up and down like a SUNBEAM; but still Old Brown said nothing at all.

author: Potter
text: Nutkin began again--

author: Potter
text: "Authur O'Bower has broken his band, He comes roaring up the land!

author: Potter
text: The King of Scots with all his power, Cannot turn Arthur of the Bower!"

author: Potter
text: Nutkin made a whirring noise to sound like the WIND, and he took a running jump right onto the head of Old Brown!

author: Potter
text: Then all at once there was a flutterment and a scufflement and a loud "Squeak!"

author: Potter
text: The other squirrels scuttered away into the bushes.

author: Potter
text: When they came back very cautiously, peeping round the tree-- there was Old Brown sitting on his door-step, quite still, with his eyes closed, as if nothing had happened.

author: Potter
text: BUT NUTKIN WAS IN HIS WAISTCOAT POCKET!

author: Potter
text: This looks like the end of the story; but it isn't.

author: Potter
text: Old Brown carried Nutkin into his house, and held him up by the tail, intending to skin him; but Nutkin pulled so very hard that his tail broke in two, and he dashed up the staircase, and escaped out of the attic window.

author: Potter
text: And to this day, if you meet Nutkin up a tree and ask him a riddle, he will throw sticks at you, and stamp his feet and scold, and shout--

author: Potter
text: "Cuck-cuck-cuck-cur-r-r-cuck-k!"
